title: Finian McGrath
text:
Finian McGrath (born 9 April 1953) is an Irish former <a href="Independent%20politicians%20in%20Ireland">Independent</a> politician who served as <a href="Minister%20of%20State%20for%20Disability">Minister of State for Disability Issues</a> from 2016 to 2020. He served as a <a href="Teachta%20D%C3%A1la">Teachta Dála</a> (TD) from 2002 to 2020.
Early and personal life.
Born in <a href="Tuam">Tuam</a>, <a href="County%20Galway">County Galway</a>, in 1953. He was educated at <a href="University%20College%20Dublin">University College Dublin</a>. He went on to become a primary school principal at Scoil Plás Mhuire for Boys in <a href="Dublin">Dublin</a>, before entering politics. He had two daughters with his wife Anne, who died in November 2009. McGrath was a contestant on the <a href="Charity%20You%27re%20a%20Star">"You're a Star" charity special</a> in summer 2005, where he came in second. He released a charity single in December 2005, which featured the Christmas song "<a href="Angels%20We%20Have%20Heard%20on%20High">Angels We Have Heard on High</a>" and the classic "<a href="Bad%2C%20Bad%20Leroy%20Brown">Bad, Bad Leroy Brown</a>". All proceeds from the sales of this single were donated to <a href="Down%20syndrome">Down syndrome</a> Ireland.
Political career.
He was an unsuccessful candidate in the <a href="Dublin%20North-Central%20%28D%C3%A1il%20constituency%29">Dublin North-Central</a> constituency at the <a href="1992%20Irish%20general%20election">1992</a> and <a href="1997%20Irish%20general%20election">1997</a> general elections. He was elected to <a href="Dublin%20City%20Council">Dublin City Council</a> in <a href="1999%20Irish%20local%20elections">1999</a>, with the second-highest vote in the <a href="Clontarf%2C%20Dublin">Clontarf</a> local electoral area. He was first elected to <a href="D%C3%A1il%20%C3%89ireann">Dáil Éireann</a> at the <a href="2002%20Irish%20general%20election">2002 general election</a>, where he stood as an <a href="Independent%20Health%20Alliance">Independent Health Alliance</a> candidate in the Dublin North-Central constituency. He joined the <a href="technical%20group">technical group</a>, established to ensure Dáil speaking time for Independent TDs. In March 2003, due to being a <a href="dual%20mandate">dual mandate</a> TD, he gave up his Dublin City Council seat to Ger Drogan, who later was replaced by Fintan Cassidy, who failed to get elected in the subsequent <a href="2004%20Irish%20local%20elections">2004 local elections</a>.
McGrath was re-elected to the <a href="30th%20D%C3%A1il">30th Dáil</a> at the <a href="2007%20Irish%20general%20election">2007 general election</a>, confounding predictions that he would lose due to the loss of a seat from the constituency. He garnered a large number of transfers from the <a href="Sinn%20F%C3%A9in">Sinn Féin</a> and <a href="Labour%20Party%20%28Ireland%29">Labour Party</a> candidates.
As an Independent member of the 30th Dáil, McGrath pledged his support for the new government formed in June 2007. In so doing, he secured a deal with <a href="Taoiseach">Taoiseach</a> <a href="Bertie%20Ahern">Bertie Ahern</a>, which he made public by entering it in the Dáil record. This public announcement was hailed by many observers who had criticised other Independent TDs such as <a href="Michael%20Lowry">Michael Lowry</a> and <a href="Jackie%20Healy-Rae">Jackie Healy-Rae</a> for keeping similar deals secret. On 20 October 2008, <a href="Fallout%20of%20the%202009%20Irish%20government%20budget">following the 2009 Budget</a>, McGrath withdrew his support for the government in protest at the abolition of an automatic medical card for the over-70s, cuts in education and the increase of the pupil-teacher ratio. Following the election of <a href="Pearse%20Doherty">Pearse Doherty</a> to the <a href="D%C3%A1il">Dáil</a>, McGrath joined the Technical group, which consisted of the Sinn Féin deputies and the Independent <a href="Maureen%20O%27Sullivan%20%28politician%29">Maureen O'Sullivan</a>. He was re-elected at the <a href="2011%20Irish%20general%20election">2011 general election</a>, where he served as chair of the Technical group.
McGrath endorsed the Independent candidate Damien O'Farrell at the <a href="2009%20Irish%20local%20elections">2009 local elections</a> for the Clontarf local electoral area in <a href="Dublin%20City%20Council">Dublin City Council</a>, who was elected topping the poll.
During the <a href="2011%20Irish%20presidential%20election">2011 presidential election</a>, McGrath initially agreed to support Senator <a href="David%20Norris%20%28politician%29">David Norris</a> for nomination as a candidate. On 2 August, Norris publicly announced at a press conference that he was withdrawing from the presidential race. This followed the decision of McGrath, and the TDs <a href="John%20Halligan%20%28politician%29">John Halligan</a> and <a href="Thomas%20Pringle%20%28politician%29">Thomas Pringle</a> to withdraw their support following revelations that Norris had written a letter to an Israeli court asking <a href="pardon">clemency</a> for his former partner <a href="Ezra%20Nawi">Ezra Nawi</a>, who was then facing criminal charges. Norris withdrew his candidacy on 2 August due to the controversy. Sinn Féin proposed <a href="Martin%20McGuinness">Martin McGuinness</a> for their nomination for a presidential candidate. McGrath agreed, along with four other independent TDs, to sign McGuinness's nomination paper.
McGrath resigned as chair of the technical group in October 2012, after a dispute with <a href="Mick%20Wallace">Mick Wallace</a>, over Wallace's participation in the loose alliance related to speaking rights in the Dáil. He joined the <a href="Independent%20Alliance%20%28Ireland%29">Independent Alliance</a> at its inception in 2016. He contested the <a href="2016%20Irish%20general%20election">2016 general election</a> under that banner, in <a href="Dublin%20Bay%20North%20%28D%C3%A1il%20constituency%29">Dublin Bay North</a> owing to the abolition of Dublin North-Central. He was re-elected to the Dáil and then entered <a href="2016%20Irish%20government%20formation">talks on government formation</a>. On 6 May 2016, he <a href="Government%20of%20the%2032nd%20D%C3%A1il">entered Government</a> with Fine Gael, under Taoiseach <a href="Enda%20Kenny">Enda Kenny</a>, as <a href="Minister%20of%20State%20for%20Disability">Minister of State for Disability Issues</a>. McGrath was also appointed a "Super Junior Minister", meaning he attends <a href="Cabinet%20%28government%29">cabinet</a> meetings but cannot vote.
In January 2020, in advance of the <a href="2020%20Irish%20general%20election">2020 general election</a>, McGrath announced that he would not be seeking re-election, but would return to other forms of political activism to support people with disabilities.
Political beliefs.
Describing himself as "someone who comes from the tradition of <a href="Wolfe%20Tone">Tone</a> and <a href="James%20Connolly">Connolly</a>", McGrath holds left-wing political views. He has cited <a href="health">health</a>, <a href="education">education</a> and <a href="disability">disability</a> as his policy priorities. He has also campaigned against the <a href="Iraq%20War">Iraq War</a> and the U.S. military's use of <a href="Shannon%20Airport">Shannon Airport</a> as a stopover, and on local environmental issues.
McGrath has spoken in support of <a href="Fidel%20Castro">Fidel Castro</a>'s <a href="Socialism">socialist</a> government in <a href="Cuba">Cuba</a>. When challenged on Cuba's supposed poor human rights record, McGrath replied that "Cuba has a different kind of democracy to Ireland."
